title: Case Study: Spastic Diplegic Cerebral Palsy in an Adolescent Male
clinical_history: Jacob is a 15-year-old adolescent male with a diagnosis of spastic diplegic cerebral palsy since infancy, attributed to premature birth at 29 weeks and prolonged neonatal intensive care unit stay. Jacob is ambulatory with the aid of bilateral forearm crutches but has a markedly crouched gait. His primary complaints are increased tightness and pain in his lower limbs, particularly after attending school or participating in adapted physical education. His parents note recent worsening of toe-walking and difficulty with transfers. He requires assistance with activities of daily living involving stairs and reports frequent muscle spasms, which sometimes disrupt his sleep. Jacob attends regular physiotherapy and uses orthoses for mobility support.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged ambulation (more than 30 minutes), physical education activities, cold weather, transitions from sitting to standing, walking on inclines or uneven surfaces.
picture: [Insert illustration showing tightness and overactivity in lower limb flexors and adductors, prone to contracture.]
easing_factors: Structured stretching routine, use of ankle-foot orthoses during daytime, warm baths in the evening, scheduled rest periods, gentle passive range of motion exercises.
past_history: Premature birth at 29 weeks; neonatal respiratory distress; multiple hospitalizations in first year of life; diagnosed with spastic diplegia at 17 months.
medical_history: No history of seizures. Mild learning difficulties but no major comorbidities. Immunizations up to date.
medications: Oral baclofen 10 mg BID for spasticity. Occasional ibuprofen for pain.
personal_history: Resident with both parents. Homeschooled until age 12, now integrated in mainstream classroom with educational assistant. Enjoys video games and wheelchair basketball.
imaging: MRI brain (at age 2): Periventricular leukomalacia consistent with prematurity. No new imaging in past 5 years.
